name: Baghdad
fun_fact: Fun fact: Masgouf (grilled carp) recipes date back to ancient Sumerian times with mentions in the Babylonian Talmud - Iraqis have been grilling fish from the Tigris the same way for over 4,000 years!

hero_dishes.name: Masgouf
hero_dishes.description: Open-cut carp from the Tigris, butterflied and slow-roasted over open fire with tamarind and turmeric
hero_dishes.origin_story: Iraq's national dish dating to Sumerian times, takes 45 min to 3 hours to prepare
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Abu Nawas Fish Restaurant on Abu Nawas Street, fish market by al-samek saed hamem

hero_dishes.name: Dolma
hero_dishes.description: Vine leaves and vegetables stuffed with lamb/beef, rice, and spices in tomato broth
hero_dishes.origin_story: Iraqi version uniquely uses pomegranate juice, served without yogurt unlike other regions

hero_dishes.name: Kubba Mosul
hero_dishes.description: Crispy deep-fried bulgur dumplings filled with spiced meat and pine nuts
hero_dishes.origin_story: Specialty from Mosul, most popular kubba variety
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Zahrat Al Khaimah on Karrada Street

hero_dishes.name: Quzi
hero_dishes.description: Slow-cooked whole lamb on fragrant rice with nuts and raisins

signature_drinks.name: Iraqi Chai
signature_drinks.description: Strong black tea, often with cardamom
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served post-meal as hospitality gesture, often complimentary

signature_drinks.name: Iraqi Coffee (Qahwa)
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: From small cups, part of hospitality tradition

food_culture_notes: Fish market is Baghdad's version of Tsukiji - watch masgouf grilled before your eyes
Soup and salad often served complimentary before meals
Iraqi hospitality means chai and coffee often free after meal
Food is celebration and connection - sharing meals shows warmth
